headline: Who Made My Magic Ring Disappear?
author: Allan Ripp
sentences: The ring falls into hands of one of Cromwell’s soldiers, then to an Ironsides cavalier and even Walpole’s mistress, before crossing the Atlantic and winding up in a New England church collection box, and finally the glass case of a Boston jeweler.

There’s a wonderful Nathaniel Hawthorne story called “The Antique Ring” about a gentleman whose fiancee asks him to compose a legend for the engagement ring he’s given her.
“An imp took it—they love stealing valuables,” Singer said, assuring us the invisible mischief maker would return it after he grew tired of toying with us mortals.
Indeed, after we’d scoured every corner of our apartment, the bracelet emerged deep in my in-laws’ sofa called the playpen—the imp surely knew what it was doing.
In 1982 I spent time with Yiddish writer Isaac Bashevis Singer, who took an interest in Sarah, especially when she told him she’d lost a gold-chain bracelet.
Into the freezer it went, wrapped in aluminum foil with other treasures marked “hamburger”—a trick my mom picked up from homemaker columnist Heloise.
But then, it showed up weeks later stuck to the bottom of a juice box buried in Sarah’s purse—proof that our kids were the sweet glue of our lives.
Inspired by the stone’s red glow, he crafts a tale about the Earl of Essex fiddling with the ring as he awaits execution in the Tower of London.
By then it was too late to return the substitute, which is how our daughter got her own Cartier decades before qualifying for such a timepiece.
The ring bestowed mystical powers in our fight against evil wizards—without it, our world might be doomed, or at least our fantasy play.
No way could such a tiny jewel be found—its disappearance reflected the tension in our marriage at the time with three children about.
With a square design and my initials etched in gold, it barely fit my pinky and mostly sat in a royal blue box for 55 years.
Hawthorne would have been intrigued by what happened to Sarah’s engagement ring, which popped from its setting in 2002.

How did it vanish?”
I hate to admit it but I was putting my 4-year-old granddaughter, Laila, through the third degree.
